title: How to Install a Wall Niche

steps.headline: Locate all the studs that fall within the desired area.
steps.description:
Use a stud finder to find and mark each stud location. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e7/Step_1_959.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e7/Step_1_959.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

www.modernniche.com

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"}

steps.headline: Determine that there are no pipes or electric lines in the desired niche location.
Place the template (cut from front of box) in the desired position.
steps.description:
Then trace around the template to create lay out lines, making certain that the lay out lines are level and do not overlap your studs. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/73\/Step_2_858.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/73\/Step_2_858.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Cut each opening carefully using your utility knife or drywall saw.
Sand the front surface around opening until it is flat.
steps.description:
Apply construction adhesive around the opening and place niche inside, using drywall screws to hold niche in place. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/8\/8f\/Step_4a_172.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/8\/8f\/Step_4a_172.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Finish using traditional drywall methods—drywall tape and mud.
steps.description:
There is a molded bead around the front of the box to guide your drywall knife and help create a smooth edge. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/bf\/Step_5_364.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/bf\/Step_5_364.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Sand when dry and re-apply mud until the surrounding area is flat and smooth.
steps.description: Then finish the wall and niche with primer and paint.

steps.headline: Apply molding, if desired.
steps.description:
Instead of finishing out the drywall, use pre-assembled molding to trim and cover the flanges. To finish, prime and paint the molding and niche. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/4c\/Frame-shown-installed_large_copy_378.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/4c\/Frame-shown-installed_large_copy_378.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Alternatively, you can mitre your own frame and assemble it before (or while) mounting it on the wall.

tyn: Painter's tape (or other marking device) to mark stud locations
Drywall mud and drywall mud knife
text:
Locate all the studs that fall within the desired area. Use a stud finder to find and mark each stud location. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e7/Step_1_959.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e7/Step_1_959.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

www.modernniche.com

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Determine that there are no pipes or electric lines in the desired niche location. Place the template (cut from front of box) in the desired position. Then trace around the template to create lay out lines, making certain that the lay out lines are level and do not overlap your studs. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/73/Step_2_858.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/7/73/Step_2_858.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cut each opening carefully using your utility knife or drywall saw. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/8/8e/Step_3a_311.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/8/8e/Step_3a_311.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Sand the front surface around opening until it is flat. Apply construction adhesive around the opening and place niche inside, using drywall screws to hold niche in place. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/8/8f/Step_4a_172.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/8/8f/Step_4a_172.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Finish using traditional drywall methods—drywall tape and mud. There is a molded bead around the front of the box to guide your drywall knife and help create a smooth edge. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/bf/Step_5_364.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/b/bf/Step_5_364.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Sand when dry and re-apply mud until the surrounding area is flat and smooth. Then finish the wall and niche with primer and paint. Apply molding, if desired. Instead of finishing out the drywall, use pre-assembled molding to trim and cover the flanges. To finish, prime and paint the molding and niche. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/4c/Frame-shown-installed_large_copy_378.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/4/4c/Frame-shown-installed_large_copy_378.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Alternatively, you can mitre your own frame and assemble it before (or while) mounting it on the wall.
sentences: Locate all the studs that fall within the desired area.
Use a stud finder to find and mark each stud location.

{"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e7/Step_1_959.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/e/e7/Step_1_959.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

www.modernniche.com

Image by: Uploader
License: Creative Commons

"} Determine that there are no pipes or electric lines in the desired niche location.
Place the template (cut from front of box) in the desired position.
Then trace around the template to create lay out lines, making certain that the lay out lines are level and do not overlap your studs.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/73\/Step_2_858.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/7\/73\/Step_2_858.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Cut each opening carefully using your utility knife or drywall saw.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/8\/8e\/Step_3a_311.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/8\/8e\/Step_3a_311.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Sand the front surface around opening until it is flat.
Apply construction adhesive around the opening and place niche inside, using drywall screws to hold niche in place.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/8\/8f\/Step_4a_172.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/8\/8f\/Step_4a_172.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Finish using traditional drywall methods—drywall tape and mud.
There is a molded bead around the front of the box to guide your drywall knife and help create a smooth edge.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/bf\/Step_5_364.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/b\/bf\/Step_5_364.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":383,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":632.8727272727273,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Sand when dry and re-apply mud until the surrounding area is flat and smooth.
Then finish the wall and niche with primer and paint.
Instead of finishing out the drywall, use pre-assembled molding to trim and cover the flanges.
To finish, prime and paint the molding and niche.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/4c\/Frame-shown-installed_large_copy_378.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/4\/4c\/Frame-shown-installed_large_copy_378.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":460,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":760,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Alternatively, you can mitre your own frame and assemble it before (or while) mounting it on the wall.
